DataElement.preferredName: External Beam Radiation Therapy Administered Malignant Neoplasm Anatomic Site Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Location of site related to the administered external beam radiation therapy.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to the administered external beam radiation therapy.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: (ray-dee-AY-shun) Radiation therapy that uses a machine to aim high-energy rays at the cancer.

Concepts.definition: Radiation therapy in which high-energy beams are delivered to the tumor from outside of the body.
The act of having given something (e.g., a medication or test).

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: actions or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process (NCI).

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A term for diseases in which abnormal cells divide without control. Cancer cells can invade nearby tissues and can spread through the bloodstream and lymphatic system to other parts of the body._Named locations of or within the body._Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A disease or condition that extends beyond the site and spreads into adjacent tissues and regional lymph nodes.

Concepts.definition: A disease or condition that extends beyond the site and spreads into adjacent tissues and regional lymph nodes.
A tumor at the original site of origin.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A tumor at the original site of origin.: An article which expresses the relation of connection or addition. It is used to conjoin a word with a word, a clause with a clause, or a sentence with a sentence.: A tumor that has spread from its original (primary) site of growth to another site, close to or distant from the primary site.  Metastasis is characteristic of advanced malignancies, but in rare instances can be seen in neoplasms lacking malignant morphology.

Concepts.definition: A tumor at the original site of origin.
An article which expresses the relation of connection or addition. It is used to conjoin a word with a word, a clause with a clause, or a sentence with a sentence.

A tumor that has spread from its original (primary) site of growth to another site, close to or distant from the primary site.  Metastasis is characteristic of advanced malignancies, but in rare instances can be seen in neoplasms lacking malignant morphology.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A tumor that has spread from its original (primary) site of growth to another site, close to or distant from the primary site.  Metastasis is characteristic of advanced malignancies, but in rare instances can be seen in neoplasms lacking malignant morphology. -- 2004

Concepts.definition: A tumor that has spread from its original (primary) site of growth to another site, close to or distant from the primary site.  Metastasis is characteristic of advanced malignancies, but in rare instances can be seen in neoplasms lacking malignant morphology.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: indication of the presence and extent of disease.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004:Named locations of, or within, the body.:Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.
Named locations of or within the body.
Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
